item.title: Dozens Killed After Typhoon Kalmaegi Brings Flooding to Central Philippines
item.description: Many of the victims drowned, the authorities said. Hundreds of thousands of people had evacuated before Typhoon Kalmaegi hit on Tuesday.

item.title: Scars in the Blue Mosque Reveal Afghanistan’s Rifts
item.description: The namesake of Mazar-i-Sharif suffered countless cracks in a 6.3-magnitude quake, but, like Afghanistan, it has endured for centuries.

item.title: Elon Musk’s $1 Trillion Payday
item.description: My colleague Jack Ewing explains the stakes ahead of a crucial Tesla board meeting.

item.title: Dick Cheney, Powerful Vice President and Washington Insider, Dies at 84
item.description: A former defense secretary and congressman, he held the nation’s No. 2 job under President George W. Bush and was an architect of policies in an era of war and economic change.

item.title: Trump Weighs Options, and Risks, for Attacks on Venezuela
item.description: President Trump has yet to make a decision, but his advisers are pressing a range of objectives — from attacking drug cartels to seizing oil fields — to try to justify ousting Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: What to Know About Canada’s New Budget
item.description: The government of Prime Minister Mark Carney unveiled a program of big spending to spur Canada’s economy and reduce its dependence on the United States.

item.title: As UK Tries to Curb Immigration, Rural Scotland Looks to Attract Foreign Workers
item.description: Bucking the anti-immigration trend in British politics, remote areas of Scotland would like to attract foreign workers to offset declining local populations.

item.title: Drone Strike Kills Dozens of Mourners at Funeral in Sudan
item.description: The attack occurred in North Kordofan, which has seen an increased military buildup as the army and paramilitary forces jockey for control of the country.

item.title: What to Know About the Legal Scandal in Israel Over Accusations of Abuse
item.description: The fallout from a legal case has reignited a highly charged debate within the country over whether Israeli soldiers accused of abusing Palestinians are held accountable.

item.title: Sara Terry, Photographer Who Captured War’s Aftermath, Dies at 70
item.description: Her haunting work focused on the lingering traces of conflict in places like Bosnia and Sierra Leone, after the firing had stopped.

item.title: TikTok and Optimism: How Rob Jetten Won Over the Netherlands
item.description: Sleek social media posts and a shift rightward on immigration helped a center-left party win last week’s election. But can its leader, Mr. Jetten, form a government?

item.title: Nigeria Resists Christian ‘Mass Murder’ Claims Amid Trump Threats
item.description: Officials have accused the United States of foreign interference and called on Washington to support the country’s democracy instead of fomenting division.

item.title: The Jamaican Families Torn Apart by Hurricane Melissa
item.description: Days after a powerful hurricane made landfall in Jamaica, thousands of residents are now homeless and trying to make sense of how they narrowly survived. The New York Times traveled to the storm’s center in Black River, and found a community destroyed — without food or clean water — where families are desperate and still traumatized after being cut off from the outside world.

item.title: Chasing Waterfalls on Portugal’s Island of Madeira
item.description: The island, a Portuguese territory, is only 35 miles long, but its mountains are laced with scenic trails, tumbling cascades and inviting villages.

item.title: Bold Assassinations Are ‘Reality Check’ in Mexico’s Cartel Fight
item.description: The murder of Mexico’s most vocal anti-crime mayor shows that, despite President Claudia Sheinbaum’s crackdown on drug cartels, the battle is just beginning.

item.title: 7 Climbers Are Killed After Avalanche Hits Base Camp in Himalayas
item.description: Rescuers in Nepal airlifted some injured climbers to safety. The avalanche followed heavy snowfall produced by Cyclone Montha.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Two-Year U.N. Mandate for Gaza Stabilization Force
item.description: A draft Security Council resolution said that an international force would ensure that Gaza be demilitarized, though specifics were unclear.

item.title: China’s Security State Sells an A.I. Dream
item.description: China’s new national drive to embrace artificial intelligence is also giving the authorities new ways to monitor and control its citizens.

item.title: After Hurricane Melissa, a Seaside Town in Jamaica Picks Up the Pieces
item.description: The devastation caused by Hurricane Melissa in Black River, Jamaica, reflects the broader destruction and rebuilding facing many Jamaican communities.

item.title: Kim Yong-nam, Longtime Ceremonial Head of North Korea, Dead at 97
item.description: In a country where political purges are frequent, Mr. Kim was a notable exception and served three generations of its dynastic rulers.

item.title: The Netherlands Will Return Looted Pharoah-Era Artifact to Egypt
item.description: The 3,500-year-old artifact, likely stolen from Egypt during the Arab Spring in 2011 or 2012, was found at an elite European art fair in Maastricht.

item.title: U.N. Report on Greenhouse Gas Emissions Finds Slight Progress
item.description: The annual U.N. report card finds that, overall, countries are still far off-track from their stated goals to limit global warming.

item.title: Ukraine Moves to Revamp Military Service
item.description: The country will introduce fixed-term military contracts to try to attract recruits and ease the strain on soldiers after years of fighting.

item.title: In ‘Kyoto,’ Seeking to Save the Earth but Veering Off Course
item.description: At Lincoln Center Theater, a new play from the makers of “The Jungle” tries to dramatize the negotiations that led to the Kyoto Protocol.

item.title: Amazon Oil Drilling Undermines Brazil’s Climate Credibility Before COP30
item.description: Brazil, which is hosting the 30th U.N. Climate Change Conference this month, wants to show the world it is a leader in safeguarding the planet. Its record tells a more complicated story.

item.title: A Big Moment for Women in India
item.description: My colleague Mujib Mashal writes about how a huge victory on the cricket ground could change the lives of women and girls.

item.title: Medieval Tower in Rome Partially Collapses, Trapping Worker Who Died After Rescue Efforts
item.description: Rescuers at the tower near the Colosseum worked for 11 hours before removing the man who had been pinned under rubble and debris. He later died in the hospital.

item.title: Mail-In Ballots Solidify Narrow Win for Dutch Centrist Party
item.description: The center-left D66 party edged the far-right party of Geert Wilders in the popular vote, giving it the first crack at forming a new government.

item.title: Arrests in Louvre Heist Show Power of DNA Databases in Solving Crimes
item.description: France’s trove of DNA profiles has helped solve high-profile crimes and was used to find some of the Louvre suspects, and it is growing. The police can also access other countries’ databases.

item.title: U.K. Police Investigate Possible Link Between Train Attack and Stabbing of 14-Year-Old
item.description: The police are examining whether the suspect in the stabbing spree on a London-bound train on Saturday was connected to three other incidents involving a knife.

item.title: Halloween Becomes Another Target of the Kremlin’s Culture Wars
item.description: The Russian authorities canceled a festival in St. Petersburg, branding it “Satanist,” as part of a larger assault on anything viewed as a Western influence.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Threat of Military Action in Nigeria
item.description: The president said he would halt all aid and go in “guns-a-blazing” to target militants.

item.title: After Fleeing a Massacre, Survivors Encountered Still More Gunfire and Abductions
item.description: Thousands of people who witnessed atrocities have tried to escape El Fasher in Sudan’s Darfur region since paramilitary fighters seized that city in late October.

item.title: India Wins Women’s Cricket World Cup
item.description: A team that faced seemingly insurmountable odds wins its first championship, with wider ramifications for the role women play in public life.

item.title: Outspoken Mexican Mayor Who Declared War on Cartels Is Killed
item.description: Mayor Carlos Manzo of Uruapan had criticized President Claudia Sheinbaum’s approach to crime. He was shot at a Day of the Dead celebration.

item.title: Another Deadly Earthquake, and a Cascade of Problems for Afghanistan
item.description: A 6.3-magnitude earthquake struck near Mazar-i-Sharif, a northern city known for its magnificent Blue Mosque, which suffered damage.

item.title: La Scala Stages New Vision of Shostakovich’s Original ‘Lady MacBeth’
item.description: Banned for decades in the Soviet Union for its dissonance and bawdiness, the opera returns as La Scala’s season opener amid the 50th anniversary of Shostakovich’s death.

item.title: In Israel, an Unfamiliar Word Is Heard: Peace
item.description: A new kind of Mideast peace process is underway, as a determined Trump administration and its allies in the Muslim world seek to broaden a tenuous cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: La Scala’s First ‘Ring’ in a Decade Passes the Wagnerian Flame
item.description: Two conductors — a mentor and a protégé, both trained as pianists — bring precision and lyricism to the first new staging of Wagner’s epic in a decade.

item.title: A Celebrated French Writer Loved Russia. War Forced a Reckoning.
item.description: Emmanuel Carrère’s best sellers on Russia grew out of a deep affection. Since Moscow invaded Ukraine, he has traveled to the war-torn country to rethink his views.

item.title: Louvre Heist: What to Know About the Suspects and Investigation
item.description: Three of the four people whom the police believe carried out the theft have been arrested. But the jewelry is nowhere to be found.

item.title: British Man Charged After Stabbing Rampage on Train
item.description: U.K. officials said they did not believe the attack on a train to London was connected to terrorism. One of the 11 people injured remains in critical condition, the police said.

item.title: Hegseth Vows Stronger Ties With a Vietnam Skeptical of U.S. Commitment
item.description: After months of uncertainty over U.S. aid, the defense secretary pledged that Washington would keep funding programs that help address the wounds of the Vietnam War.

item.title: In Switzerland, The Alps Are Melting Amid Climate Change, but Villagers Won’t Be Moved
item.description: Switzerland is racing to rebuild Blatten, which was crushed by a glacier. It’s a sign of the economic and emotional costs of a warming Europe.

item.title: Inspired by Rome’s Pantheon: Antony Gormley and Tadao Ando’s Art Cave
item.description: The British sculptor Antony Gormley and the Japanese architect Tadao Ando designed an installation evoking the ancient Roman dome. Building it was complicated.

item.title: That Time Xi Jinping Joked About Espionage
item.description: Xi Jinping gave two cellphones to South Korea’s president, who asked how secure they were. “You can check if there’s a backdoor,” he said with a laugh.

item.title: A Massacre Unfolding in Sudan
item.description: My colleague Declan Walsh writes about the humanitarian crisis in Darfur — and how the world is now largely looking away.

item.title: Defense Lawyers Demand Dismissal of Abuse Case Against Israeli Soldiers
item.description: The chief legal officer of Israel’s military resigned after authorizing the leak of a video in the case involving grave abuse of a Palestinian detainee. That further politicized a fraught case.

item.title: For Day of the Dead, One Mexican Town Digs Up Its Dead
item.description: Pomuch, Mexico, is one of the last places where residents clean their relatives’ bones. Now they are grappling with a new challenge: tourists.

item.title: 5 German Climbers Are Killed by Avalanche in Italian Alps
item.description: The climbers were in two groups in northern Italy on Saturday night when an avalanche struck. Two people survived.

item.title: Communities in Hurricane-Ravaged Jamaica Still Cut Off as Death Toll Climbs
item.description: The authorities have yet to reach dozens of areas in Jamaica, raising the question of how many people really died in last week’s storm.

item.title: Canadians Mourn a Loss by Underdogs Who Brought a Nation Together
item.description: The Blue Jays, Canada’s only M.L.B. team, were a salve for a country hit by President Trump’s threats and tariffs. Then the Dodgers ended their thrilling postseason run.

item.title: Meet Your News Friend, the New Host of The Morning
item.description: Sam Sifton wants readers to know: Everything is going to be all right, and you’re not alone.

item.title: The New Host of The Morning
item.description: I’m Sam Sifton. Before we get to the news today, I’d like to tell you a little about myself. You ought to know who’s writing to you.

item.title: Cleaning Bones for Day of the Dead
item.description: Practitioners of an annual ritual to clean deceased relatives’ bones are grappling with a new challenge: tourists. Jack Nicas, our Mexico City bureau chief, visits Pomuch, a town in Eastern Mexico that celebrates Día de Muertos unlike any other place.

item.title: The Economic Crisis in Egypt Raises Another Dilemma: Tipping
item.description: Waiters and deliverymen receive tips. But so do receptionists, government clerks and hospital nurses. And with Egypt stuck in an economic crisis, even the cost of tipping is inflating.

item.title: An Outlier in Irish Politics Has Become the Country’s President
item.description: Propelled by anti-establishment fervor, Catherine Connolly was elected last week with a landmark popular mandate.

item.title: See How Thailand’s Pets Become Speed Eating Contest Champions
item.description: Speed eating contests are part of a growing list of pet-related events in Thailand that also include competitions for skateboarding dogs and felines that look like cows.
